Name: Battle Basics
Description: Turns alternate between the player side and the enemy side. Each character can normally do one action on their turn.
InfoBox: Turns alternate between the player side and the enemy side. Each character can normally do one action on their turn. On your turn, if both characters are available to act, you can use the <buttonsprite,B> button to switch who will act next or the <buttonsprite,Z> button to swap positions. Switching positions can also be done through the Tactics menu.

Name: Multiple Actions
Description: You can get <effect,BonusTurns> multiple actions per turn, but each action after the first makes all skills cost 25% more. You can pass actions by using Turn Relay in the Tactics menu.
InfoBox: You can get  <effect,BonusTurns> multiple actions per turn, but each action after the first makes all skills cost 25% more. You can pass actions by using Turn Relay in the Tactics menu.<line><line>This can be especially useful if one character has more attack power than the other, or if there is a large group of enemies only one character can deal with.

Name: Tactics Menu
Description: The Tactics menu includes various utility actions, such as fleeing battle or seeing enemy stats.
InfoBox: The Tactics menu includes various utility actions, such as fleeing battle or seeing enemy stats.<line><line>The Check action gives you basic information about the enemy, and does not take up your turn. The Scan action allows you to let Keru to scan the enemy, giving you more thorough information about the enemy including their entire moveset. However, Scanning will take up your turn, unlike Checking.<next>The Rest action passes your turn, while also giving you 3 Soul Energy and bonus Stamina equal to your Agility.<line><line>The Flee action makes you flee the battle. Fleeing costs Stamina, and the cost is based on the strength of every enemy that can move, so killing them or inflicting ailments on them can reduce the cost. The cost of the Flee action is also capped at your max Stamina.<line><line>Turn Relay is a very useful action that allows you to pass your action to the other character.

Name: Agility and <stamina> Stamina
Description: Stamina is a secondary resource used to pay for moves alongside Energy. Agility is a stat that determines the rate that you gain stamina, and it is proportional to Max EP.
InfoBox: Stamina is a secondary resource used to pay for moves alongside Energy. Agility is a stat that determines the rate that you gain stamina, and it is proportional to Max EP.<line><line>Agility is calculated by adding 7 to your Max EP and then dividing by a certain factor and then rounding up. This factor is 12 for Wilex and 16 for Luna.<line><line>If you use a move whose stamina cost is higher than your Agility, you won't get any stamina next turn. The character in front also has their agility increased by 33%.

Name: <SP> SP and <SE> SE
Description: <SP> Soul Points are a stat that affects your <SE> Max Soul Energy, and also affects how many badges you can equip.
InfoBox: <SP> Soul Points are a stat that affects your <SE> Max Soul Energy, and also affects how many badges you can equip.<line><line>Your <SE> Max Soul Energy is equal to your <SP> Soul Points, except if you have something that increases your <SE> Max Soul Energy. Badges cost <SP> Soul Points. Some Badges are equipped on a single character, while others are equipped to the whole party.

Name: <badge,BadgeSwap> Badges
Description: Badges provide bonuses, new abilities in battle, affect your stats or affect the course of battle in other ways.
InfoBox: Badges provide bonuses, new abilities in battle, affect your stats or affect the course of battle in other ways.<line><line>You can equip or unequip badges in the Equip menu. The Equip menu can also be sorted using the <buttonsprite,z> button. Each badge costs a certain amount of <SP> Soul Points. Soul Points are one of the three stats you can raise upon leveling up.

Name: <ribbon,SafetyRibbon> Ribbons
Description: Ribbons give you an additional method of blocking, as well as providing an effect that occurs when you use the Rest action.
InfoBox: Ribbons give you an additional method of blocking, as well as providing an effect that occurs when you use the Rest action.<line><line>Ribbons can be equipped in the Ribbons subsection of the Equip menu. You can also review the effects of each ribbon in that menu. Each character can only equip one ribbon at a time, and you can't equip one ribbon to multiple characters. However, there exists a <ribbon,mimicribbon> ribbon that copies the effect of the other character's ribbon. There is also a <badge,ribbonpower> badge that can strengthen the effect when you use Rest while wearing ribbons.

Name: <item,carrot> Items
Description: Normal items can be consumed in battle or the overworld in the pause menu.
InfoBox: Normal items can be consumed in battle or the overworld in the pause menu.<line><line>In the overworld, Items can be used in the Item menu. However, some items can only be used in battle (i.e. <item,staticthorn> attacking items).<line><line>Some Key Items can also be consumed in the Key Item menu.

Name: <item,carrot,echo> Item Modifiers
Description: Item Modifiers are special modifiers that can be applied to all items. Enabling this option in the Lobby will make items much stronger (and more expensive), so the game will become easier.
InfoBox: Item Modifiers are special modifiers that can be applied to all items. Enabling this option in the Lobby will make items much stronger (and more expensive), so the game will become easier.<line><line>Each modifier is equally likely to appear with this option enabled except Focus only appears on normally multi target items, Spread only appears on normally single target items, and Echoed will not appear normally.<next><color,#f00000>(F)</color> Focus: Item becomes single target but 2x as strong.<line><color,#0090f0>(S)</color> Spread: Item becomes multi target<line><color,#00f000>(E)</color> Echo: Item is 0.8x as strong but becomes Echoed.<line><color,#90f090>(e)</color> Echoed: Item is 0.4x as strong (created by an Echo copy).<line><color,#f0c000>(G)</color> Glistening: Item is 1.5x as strong<line><color,#7000f0>(V)</color> Void: Item does not take up space.<line><color,#909090>(Q)</color> Quick: Item does not take your action when used (but can't use items immediately after)

Name: Enemy Behavior
Description: Enemies tend to target the front character twice as often as they target the back character. Enemy behavior also tends to be deterministic.
InfoBox: Enemies tend to target the front character twice as often as they target the back character.<line><line>Enemy behavior also tends to be deterministic, though their behavior may depend on what other enemies are in the formation and what turn it is, with a few enemies acting different based on your hp.

Name: Item Drops
Description: Enemies will drop items once every 4 battles, but this rate goes up to once every 2 battles if you got no XP from the battle.
InfoBox: Enemies will drop items once every 4 battles, but this rate goes up to once every 2 battles if you got no XP from the battle.<line><line>Items will drop more often if you have 4 or less items in your inventory, and are guaranteed to drop if you have 2 or less items in your inventory.<line><line>Curse badges will also increase the item drop rate.<next>Certain strong enemies will always drop items. Each enemy type has an item it can drop if you start a fight with it in the overworld.<line><line>Stacking enough effects that increase item drop rate will cause the drop rate to go above 100%, making it possible to get multiple items from one battle.

Name: Curse Badges
Description: Curse Badges increase the difficulty of the game by multiplying enemy stats by a certain amount and changing their moves in a certain way.
InfoBox: Curse Badges increase the difficulty of the game by multiplying enemy stats by a certain amount and changing their moves in a certain way, while also increasing the rewards from battle.<next>More specifically, enemy Max HP, Attack, Coin drops and Experience drops are all multiplied. Each enemy type has at least one change to their moveset exclusive to difficulties higher than normal. Items will also drop more often from normal enemy battles as well. Attacks are guaranteed to deal at least 1 more damage than with the previous curse level (i.e. with Super Curse, all attacks will deal at least 1 more damage than normal.)<next>Boss fights are expected to be barely possible with Mega Curse, requiring very advanced strategy and often requiring grinding to the maximum possible stats you can obtain as well as cooking an inventory full of the best possible items.<line><line>Curse badges can be combined to be stacked together, but this will likely result in many required fights becoming completely impossible.

Name: <xp> Experience
Description: <xp> Experience points are earned by defeating enemies of a higher level than you. You level up once you obtain 100 of them.
InfoBox: Experience points are earned by defeating enemies of a higher level than you. You level up once you obtain 100 of them.<line><line>The amount of experience you get from a certain enemy is proportional to the difference between their level and yours. The experience bonus increases their level in the formula unless your level is equal or greater than theirs.<line><line>Enemies also drop more experience in encounters that start with more enemies.<next>The Curse badges will increase the experience enemies give out in proportion to their multiplier. However, each curse badge is guaranteed to add 1 to the experience the enemy gives out if the enemy gives out more than 0 experience.

Name: <state,StateContactHazard> Contact Hazards
Description: Contact Hazards deal damage to you when you attack an enemy that has them. The only two types of contact hazards are ones that apply on direct contact and ones that apply on weapon moves.
InfoBox: Contact Hazards deal damage to you when you attack an enemy that has them. Different types of contact hazards include ones that apply on direct contact <state,StateContactHazard> and rarer ones that apply on weapon moves as well as contact moves <state,StateContactHazardHeavy>.<line><line>Contact hazards can never interrupt your moves, but they can reduce you to 0 hp. Each enemy can only deal contact damage to you once per turn, so a multihit move against a single target will only ever result in you taking damage a single time.<next>However, multitarget moves will result in you taking damage multiple times if you target multiple enemies that have contact hazards.

Name: <state,StateCounter> Counters
Description: Some enemies will counterattack you when you attack them. Other enemies may react in other ways when you attack them, but the symbol only appears when the enemy specifically attacks you in response to being attacked.
InfoBox: Some enemies will counterattack you when you attack them. Other enemies may react in other ways when you attack them, but the symbol only appears when the enemy specifically attacks you in response to being attacked.<line><line>Higher difficulties will make many more enemies react to being hit. There are also some rare cases where enemies will counter attacks made against their allies as well (<state,StateCounterHeavy>).

Name: <state,ElectricWind> Environmental Effects
Description: Environmental effects are global effects caused by the environment you are in. These are tied to each biome or region. The Curse badges will make environmental effects stronger, often making them have compounding effects. The <badge,WeatherShield> Weather Shield badge reduces the strength of environmental effects by half, but there are some rare, strong environmental effects that are not affected by it.
InfoBox: Environmental effects are global effects caused by the environment you are in. These are tied to each biome or region. The Curse badges will make environmental effects stronger, often making them have compounding effects. The <badge,WeatherShield> Weather Shield badge reduces the strength of environmental effects by half, but there are some rare, strong environmental effects that are not affected by it.

Name: <state,CharmAttack> Charms
Description: Charms are special effects that can persist over multiple battles over the course of a certain amount of turns.
InfoBox: Charms are special effects that can persist over multiple battles over the course of a certain amount of turns.<line><line>Power Charms have a certain amount of charges and a certain frequency with which they activate. They alternate between giving you Focus and Absorb on each activation. Fortune Charms passively last a certain amount of turns and greately boost XP and coin drops from enemies while active.<next>Totems are Key Items that can provide you the effect of a charm when used, but you can only carry one Totem of each type at a time.

Name: <state,HealthRest> Rest Effects
Description: Rest Effects are effects that last a certain number of battles and apply at the start of each battle.
InfoBox: Rest Effects are effects that last a certain number of battles and apply at the start of each battle.<line><line>Different inns around the world provide different Rest Effects. Most of the time, they last for the next 3 battles, although Rest Effects that heal certain stats will last 4 battles instead, while some more powerful Rest Effects will last only 2 battles.<line><line>Candles are Key Items that give you a full heal as if you stayed at an inn as well as the Rest Effect, but you can only carry one Candle at a time.

Name: Damage Reduction
Description: Effects that reduce incoming damage by a certain percentage stack do not stack linearly. Instead, each effect is given a certain number of Resistance Points (0.33 reduction = 1 point, 0.5 reduction = 2 points)
InfoBox: Effects that reduce incoming damage by a certain percentage stack do not stack linearly. Instead, each effect is given a certain number of Resistance Points (0.33 reduction = 1 point, 0.5 reduction = 2 points)<line><line>The formula for damage reduction is (R / (2 + R)) where R is the total number of resistance points you have (so 1 point is a reduction of 33%, 2 points is a reduction of 50% and so on.)

Name: <badge,EnergyShield> Shield Payment
Description: Certain <badge,EnergyShield> damage reduction effects require you to pay with a certain resource for each point of damage reduced. If you have multiple damage reduction effects active, you pay a lower amount.
InfoBox: Certain <badge,EnergyShield> damage reduction effects require you to pay with a certain resource for each point of damage reduced. If you have multiple damage reduction effects active, you pay a lower amount.<line><line>More specifically, the amount you pay is multiplied by the ratio of how many resistance points are contributed by the effect divided by how many resistance points you have total.<next>For example, suppose you have 4 resistance points with 2 points coming from an effect you have to pay for. If the damage from a certain attack is reduced by 10, then the amount you pay is the same as if the damage was reduced by 5 and you only had the effect you had to pay for

Name: Status Effects
Description: Status Effects modify the behavior or stats of enemies. The duration of an effect is on the bottom right of the icon, and the potency is on the top left.
InfoBox: Status Effects modify the behavior or stats of enemies. The duration of an effect is on the bottom right of the icon, and the potency is on the top left. <effect,Poison> Ailments do not have potency, and <effect,Focus> tokens do not have duration. An effect with a duration of X is an effect with infinite duration, so it will last forever.<next>All effects on all entities will have their durations tick down after all enemies have moved. Certain effects will apply when the durations tick down (i.e. something like <effect,Poison> Poison will deal damage at this time).

Name: <effect,Poison> Ailments
Description: Ailments are debilitating effects that usually prevent an enemy from moving or severely reduce their capabilities.  Normal ailments are <effect,Berserk> Berserk, <effect,Sleep> Sleep, <effect,Paralyze> Paralyze, <effect,Dizzy> Dizzy, <effect,Freeze> Freeze and <effect,Poison> Poison.
InfoBox: Ailments are debilitating effects that usually prevent an enemy from moving or severely reduce their capabilities. Normal ailments are <effect,Berserk> Berserk, <effect,Sleep> Sleep, <effect,Paralyze> Paralyze, <effect,Dizzy> Dizzy, <effect,Freeze> Freeze and <effect,Poison> Poison.<line><line>Enemies can only have one ailment at a time. Each enemy type can have a different susceptibility to different ailments. Ailment inflicting moves against enemies work based on enemy HP and are not random. Enemies can also have different turn modifiers for each ailment, making them last longer or shorter against them.<next>Each enemy has a certain maximum number of turns they can be ailed, after which, it will become impossible to ail them again. Enemies also become less susceptible the more turns they have been ailed, proportional to their maximum ailment turns. <line><line>For example, an enemy with a maximum ailment turn count of 4 will become 25% less susceptible to all ailments for each turn of ailment inflicted against them.<next>Enemies can have moves that try to inflict ailments against you. You can block in order to reduce the duration of the inflicted ailment by 1.

Name: Buffs, Debuffs and Tokens
Description: Buffs, Debuffs and Tokens are temporary effects that can be applied in various ways.
InfoBox: Buffs, Debuffs and Tokens are temporary effects that can be applied in various ways. <effect,AttackUp> Buffs and <effect,AttackDown> Debuffs have duration and potency, while <effect,Focus>Tokens only have potency and they usually last indefinitely until certain conditions are met, usually when their effect is applied.<line><line>Unlike <effect,Poison> ailments, you can usually inflict an unlimited number of <effect,AttackDown> debuffs and <effect,Defocus> negative tokens on enemies.<next>Like with <effect,Poison> ailments, enemies may have <effect,AttackDown> debuff inflicting moves, which you can reduce the duration of by blocking. You can also reduce the potency of <effect,Defocus> negative tokens by blocking as well.

Name: Buff Stacking
Description: Attempting to apply a buff on a target that already has the same buff will cause the buff to have the potency of the stronger effect and a duration that is a certain amount longer than the stronger effect.
InfoBox: Attempting to apply a buff on a target that already has the same buff will cause the buff to have the potency of the stronger effect and a duration that is a certain amount longer than the stronger effect.<line><line>More specifically, the duration is calculated in the following way.<line>Effect Power = Duration A * Potency A + Duration B * Potency B<line>New Duration = Effect Power / New Potency (rounded down).<next>However, you are guaranteed to get at least 1 bonus turn.<line><line>It is not possible to stack buffs and debuffs with infinite duration. Tokens stack by adding potencies together, but there is a limit to stacking Focus and Absorb.

Name: Buff and Debuff Stacking
Description: Attempting to apply a buff on a target that has an opposite debuff (or vice versa) will cause the effect to have the duration of the effect with a longer duration and a potency in between the two effects.
InfoBox: Attempting to apply a buff on a target that has an opposite debuff (or vice versa) will cause the effect to have the duration of the effect with a longer duration and a potency in between the two effects.<line><line>More specifically, the potency is calculated in the following way (with Potency A and Duration A being the stronger effect)<line>New Potency = ((Duration A * Potency A) - (Duration B * Potency B)) / New Duration (rounded down)<next>However, stronger effect is guaranteed to be left with at least 1 potency. If one of the effects has infinite duration, then the potency will just be the potency of the stronger effect minus the weaker effect.

Name: <effect,Berserk> Berserk
Description: Berserk is an ailment that increases the target's attack by 1 but reduces their defense by 1. The target is also forced to target the one who inflicted the ailment.
InfoBox: Berserk is an ailment that increases the target's attack by 1 but reduces their defense by 1. The target is also forced to target the one who inflicted the ailment. If this is not possible, they will target opponents normally. However,  which moves an enemy chooses to use are unaffected by Berserk, so a Berserk enemy may still use healing moves or multitarget moves. If an enemy inflicts you with Berserk, you will automatically use your base weapon move against it, or your base jump move if the weapon move can't be used.<next>However, if you become Berserk in some other way (or if you can't target the enemy that made you Berserk), you will alternate between using your base weapon move and your base jump move every other turn, targetting the frontmost target. In either case, you will block automatically while Berserk.<line><line>Berserk is the least useful ailment to inflict upon enemies, but it has some marginal usefulness if you want to make enemies target a specific character.

Name: <effect,Sleep> Sleep
Description: Sleep is an ailment that prevents movement but causes the target to regenerate 10% of their Max HP every turn (clamped between 2 and 10 hp). Attacking a sleeping target wakes them up.
InfoBox: Sleep is an ailment that prevents movement, but causes the target to regenerate 10% of their Max HP every turn (clamped between 2 and 10 hp). Attacking a sleeping target wakes them up.<line><line>Inflicting Sleep upon enemies is useful at the start of battles, as the regeneration will not have any effect when the enemy is at max hp.

Name: <effect,Paralyze> Paralyze
Description: Paralyze is an ailment that reduces attack power by half.
InfoBox: Paralyze is an ailment that reduces attack power by half.<line><line>Inflicting Paralyze upon enemies is useful when you want to reduce the damage you take.

Name: <effect,Dizzy> Dizzy
Description: Dizzy is an ailment that causes all of the target's attacks to miss.
InfoBox: Dizzy is an ailment that causes all of the target's attacks to miss.<line><line>Dizzy is one of the best ailmentes to inflict upon enemies, but dizzy enemies can still perform actions that aren't attacks.

Name: <effect,Freeze> Freeze
Description: Freeze is an ailment that prevents movement and reduces the target's defense by 1. Frozen targets become unfrozen when they take damage.
InfoBox: Freeze is an ailment that prevents movement and reduces the target's defense by 1. Frozen targets become unfrozen when they take damage.<line><line>Freezing enemies is very useful if you want to focus your attacks on other enemies.

Name: <effect,Poison> Poison
Description: Poison is an ailment that causes the target to take damage every turn equal to 10% of their Max HP (clamped between 2 and 10 hp).
InfoBox: Poison is an ailment that causes the target to take damage every turn equal to 10% of their Max HP (clamped between 2 and 10 hp).<line><line>While it doesn't restrict movement like the other ailmentes, Poison is still useful for dealing passive damage to enemies, or bypassing their defenses.

Name: Light Damage
Description: Light element is stronger against enemies at high hp, up to a +0.66x boost.
InfoBox: Light element is stronger against enemies at high hp, up to a +0.66x boost.<line><line>More specifically, the boost is a multiplier equal to (1 + (current hp / max hp)). Light damage is best used at the start of battle when all the enemies are at max hp.<line><line>If enemies are using light damage against you, you may want to avoid healing as long as possible in order to reduce the damage they deal.

Name: Dark Damage
Description: Dark element is stronger against enemies at low hp, up to a +1.0x boost.
InfoBox: Dark element is stronger against enemies at low hp, up to a +1.0x boost.<line><line>More specifically, the boost is a multiplier equal to (2 - (current hp / max hp)). Dark damage is best used against bosses when their hp is low.<line><line>If enemies are using Dark damage against you, you may want to heal more often than usual in order to avoid taking more damage.

Name: Earth Damage
Description: Earth damage is boosted based on damage the user took this turn and last turn, up to +0.66x base damage
InfoBox: Earth damage is boosted based on damage the user took this turn and last turn, up to +0.66x base damage<line><line>Earth damage can reward damage takning strategies, as taking damage will boost your Earth damage.<line><line>If enemies are using Earth damage against you, you can move slowly to avoid taking stronger attacks for longer, or you can try to take them out quickly so they don't have an opportunity to attack, though some Earth damage users have counter attacks.

Name: Air Damage
Description: Air/Electric damage pierces defense except for specifically air/electric defense.
InfoBox: Air/Electric damage pierces defense except for specifically air/electric defense.<line><line>Air/Electric damage is best used against high defense enemies.<line><line>If enemies are using Air/Electric damage against you, you should avoid using defense boosts as they will not be useful.

Name: Water Damage
Description: Water damage is stronger when the user is at high HP, up to a +0.66x boost.
InfoBox: Water damage is stronger when the user is at high HP, up to a +0.66x boost.<line><line>Water damage is best used along more patient and defensive strategies.<line><line>If enemies are using Water damage against you, using spread damage to slowly whittle their health down may help you avoid taking high damage from their attacks.

Name: Fire Damage
Description: Fire damage gets boosted up to +1.0x based on how low your HP percentage is.
InfoBox: Fire damage gets boosted up to +1.0x based on how low your HP percentage is.<line><line>Fire damage is best suited for risky and aggressive strategies where you stay at low health as long as possible.<line><line>If enemies are using Fire damage against you, you should try to focus your attention at one at a time, to avoid leaving some of them at low health and giving them the opportunity to use stronger attacks.

Name: Prismatic Damage
Description: Prismatic damage has no special modifiers, but enemies usually have no defense against Prismatic damage.
InfoBox: Prismatic damage has no special modifiers. However, enemy defense to Prismatic damage is equal to the lowest elemental defense that enemy has, which is usually 0 with Air/Electric damage.<line><line>Prismatic damage is very strong against enemies with major weaknesses to other elements.

Name: Void Damage
Description: Void damage has no special modifiers, and enemies usually have no defense against Void damage.
InfoBox: Void damage has no special modifiers, and enemies usually have no defense against Void damage. Enemy defense to Void damage is equal to the lowest elemental defense that enemy has, which is usually 0 with Air/Electric damage.<line><line>Void damage and Prismatic damage are very similar, but there are very few sources of these damage types.

Name: Advanced Elements
Description: In rare cases, elemental damage may use the "advanced" formulas instead of their normal ones, and the particle effects will be slightly different.
InfoBox: In rare cases, elemental damage may use the "advanced" formulas instead of their normal ones, and the particle effects will be slightly different.<next>Light: Damage multiplier =<line>2 - |Attacker HP % - Defender HP %|<line><line>Dark: Damage multiplier:<line>1 + |Attacker HP % - Defender HP %|<line><line>Earth: Boosted based on user damage taken as well as target damage taken (this turn and last turn), capped at +1.0x<next>Air: Deals additional damage based on enemy defense, up to a maximum of a +1.0x boost.<line><line>Water: Boosted based on party average HP (i.e. boosted at high average percentage)<line><line>Fire: The damage treats attack reducing effects as buffs, Boosted based on party average HP (i.e. boosted at low average percentage)

Name: Advanced Ailments
Description: There are nine advanced ailments that are not available for you to use, and are very rarely inflicted by enemies and bosses (with many of these opportunities only occuring in higher difficulties.)
InfoBox: There are nine advanced ailments that are not available for you to use, and are very rarely inflicted by enemies and bosses (with most of these opportunities only occuring in higher difficulties.)<line><line>These ailments are <effect,Soulbleed> Soulbleed, <effect,Sunflame> Sunflame, <effect,Brittle>Brittle, <effect,Inverted> Inverted, <effect,Splotch>Splotch, <effect,Dread> Dread, <effect,ArcDischarge>Arc Discharge, <effect,TimeStop> Time Stop and <effect,Exhausted> Exhausted.

Name: Multi Element Attacks
Description: In general, the damage of a multi element attack receives all the boosts from the other types independently (except in the case of Light and Dark).
InfoBox: In general, the damage of a multi element attack receives all the boosts from the other types independently (except in the case of Light and Dark). In terms of calculating defense, the attack uses the lowest defense out of the elements it is.<line><line>If an attack deals both Light and Dark damage at the same time, the formula for the damage boost changes to be boosted based on whether the enemy is at low or high hp. More specifically, the formula for their damage together is:<line>Max((4 * Current HP / Max HP) - 2, 2 - (4 * Current HP / Max HP)).<next>Likewise, something similar happens for Water and Fire damage at the same time, the formula for the damage boost changes to be boosted based on whether the user is at low or high hp. More specifically, the formula for their damage together is:<line>Max((4 * Current HP / Max HP) - 2, 2 - (4 * Current HP / Max HP)).
